intro: Rhinanthus crista-galli var. pilosa, commonly known as the hairy dog's-tongue, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family, which includes many parasitic and semi-parasitic species. The plant is characterized by its yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late summer, typically from July to August. Its leaves are opposite and often covered in fine hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in grasslands, wastelands, and along roadsides.
